questions.text: A 67 yr old with IHD, HT, hyperlipidemia and atrial fibrillation visited a general practitioner for yearly health check-up and was found to have elevated uric acid levels. He was diagnosed to have asymptomatic gout. However, based on his elevated uric acid levels, he was prescribed an anti-gout drug. Two weeks later, he was admitted in hospital with features as in the image. Which drug would have caused this?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Allopurinol hypersensitivity syndrome, which is commonly seen in patients who have HLA *B 5801 allele. There is a mortality risk of <25% mortality

The cutaneous reaction caused by allopurinol is predominantly a pruritic, erythematous, or maculopapular eruption, but occasionally, the lesion is urticarial or purpuric. Rarely, toxic epidermal necrolysis or Stevens-Johnson syndrome occurs, which can be fatal.

The risk for Stevens-Johnson syndrome is limited primarily to the first 2 months of treatment. Because the rash may precede severe hypersensitivity reactions, patients who develop a rash should discontinue allopurinol. Among polymorphic genetic factors that appear to contribute to such delayed hypersensitivity reactions is the human leucocyte antigen B*5801 allele (HLA-B*5801)

questions.text:
Cardiovascular effects of a new drug (X) that activates autonomic receptors are shown below

The most probable receptor affinities of the drug X would be
questions.solution:
A decrease in mean blood pressure, an increase in pulse pressure, plus a marked increase in heart rate are characteristic of a drug such as isoproterenol. Peripheral vascular resistance and mean BP are decreased because of activation of β2 receptors in the vasculature.

Systolic BP decreases to a lesser extent than diastolic BP because of activation of β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increase in stroke volume, as well as the increase in heart rate.

Beta receptors in the heart:

  • The human heart expresses β1- and β2-adrenergic receptors at a ratio of about 70:30; both subtypes increase heart rate and contractility.
  • In addition, β3-receptors have been described to mediate negative inotropic effects, but their role remains uncertain.
  • All three subtypes appear to occur in cardiomyocytes, but they seem to possess distinct intracellular signaling and functional properties

questions.text: A patient with choriocarcinoma was prescribed an anti-cancer drug and she returned with these lesions. Which of the following drugs could have prevented this side effect?
questions.solution:
• Oral mucositis is a severe and frequent adverse effect of high-dose methotrexate (HD-MTX)-based chemotherapy. Mucositis usually occurs within the first 7 days of administration of MTX, prior to the onset of pancytopenia, as the accumulation of MTX is higher in mucosal epithelial cells than in the bone marrow stem cells.
  • Cutaneous involvement usually appears with mucositis.
  • Mucositis is associated with an increased risk of life-threatening infections, Need for total parenteral nutrition.. For many patients with grades III–IV mucositis, the subsequent cycle of chemotherapy is delayed. A grade IV mucositis is an emergency in oncology. the updated guidelines of the Multinational Association of Supportive Care in Cancer recommend the use of palifermin in patients who are receiving high-dose chemotherapy and total body irradiation with autologous stem-cell transplantation (level 1, grade A recommendation)
  • Mucositis is due to the direct drug toxicity in epithelial cells. Histologically, this toxicity is evidenced by severe keratinocyte necrosis.
  • Palifermin is a recombinant human keratinocyte growth factor (KGF) which is known to stimulate growth of epithelial cells in a wide variety of tissues. KGF receptors are present on epithelial cells in many tissues including the tongue, buccal mucosa, salivary gland, esophagus, stomach, intestine, lung, liver, pancreas, kidney, bladder, mammary gland and eye lens
  • Mechanism of action of palifermin in mucositis:
    • Down-regulation of proinflammatory cytokines and increases anti-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-13.
    • Protection of the epithelium against reactive oxygen molecules by modifying the expression of detoxifying transcription factors and enzymes

questions.text: A 30-yr old female infected with Pseudomonas is to be treated with a combination of aminoglycoside and cephalosporin. Which of the following aminoglycosides is preferred?
questions.solution:
• There is an increased likelihood of synergistic nephrotoxic aminoglycoside-cephalosporin interaction.
  • There are two schools of thought towards combination therapy of Beta lactams(Cephalosporins) and Aminoglycoside.
  1. The argument against the addition of a second antimicrobial agent to treat a Gram-negative organism that is susceptible to a single agent is that it may actually lead to increased antimicrobial resistance, adverse effects such as aminoglycoside-related nephrotoxicity.
  2. The argument towards combination therapy may still be warranted for certain subpopulations – e.g.Profoundly neutropenic patients, patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosasepsis, intensive care unit (ICU) patients, patients with VAP(Ventilaor-Associated Pneumonia), or septic patients with significantly elevated severity-of-illness scores.

NEPHROTOXICITY OF AMINOGLYCOSIDES:

Aminoglycosides are nephrotoxic because a small but sizable proportion of the administered dose (≈5%) is retained in the epithelial cells lining the S1 and S2 segments of the proximal tubules after glomerular filtration.

Risk factors in aminoglycoside nephrotoxicity:

  • Dose and duration of drug treatment
  • Pre-existing renal insufficiency
  • Elderly age
  • Concomitant nephrotoxic drug administration
  • Volume depletion
  • Potassium depletion
  • Magnesium depletion

questions.text: Administering inhaled corticosteroids along with beta-2 agonists results in tolerance to certain effects of the latter. Which of the following is an exception to this?
questions.solution:
Because, Steroids fail to reach airway smooth muscles in high enough concentrations like beta 2 agonists.

Inhaled corticosteroids

These are glucocorticoids with high topical and low systemic activity (due to poor absorption and/or marked first pass metabolism).

Beclomethasone dipropionate, Budesonide, Fluticasone and Ciclesonide are the commonly used ICS. Because airway inflammation is present in early mild disease as well, and bronchial remodeling starts developing from the beginning, it has been advocated that ICS should be the ‘step one’ for all asthma patients.

They are indicated in all cases of persistent asthma when inhaled β2 agonists are required almost daily or the disease is not only episodic.

Inhaled corticosteroids suppress bronchial inflammation, increase peak expiratory flow rate, reduce need for rescue β2-agonist inhalations and prevent episodes of acute asthma.

questions.text: A 30-yr old man has been treated with a drug acting on the autonomic system for 4 weeks. He is now admitted with signs of drug toxicity. Which of the following signs would distinguish between an overdose of ganglion blocker and a muscarinic blocker?
questions.solution:
Neither ganglion blockers nor muscarinic blockers cause miosis; they cause mydriasis. Both classes of cholinoceptor blockers increase resting heart rate and cause cycloplegia, because these are determined largely by parasympathetic tone. Similarly, both can cause dry skin, since this requires cholinergic transmission. Postural hypotension, on the other hand, is a sign of sympathetic blockade, which would occur with ganglion blockers but not muscarinic blockers

questions.text: 'Sequential nephron blockade' with diuretics has the following advantage:
questions.solution:
Resistance to diuretics can develop by

  1. Pharmacokinetic mechanism – Amount of free diuretic reaching the site of action and diuretic’s time course of delivery to urine.
  2. Pharmacodynamic mechanism – The effect of diuretics can be counteracted by adaptation response which increases reabsorption of sodium in other areas of nephron.

This resistance development can be prevented by administering loop diuretics and thiazides together, which tend to block the reabsorption of sodium in various parts of the nephron which prevents the development of adaptation.

Reference: Goodman and Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics, 14th edition, page no. 571

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the parenteral administration of alteplase?
questions.solution:
Alteplase is thrombolytic (or “fibrinolytic”) because it activates plasminogen, resulting in the increased formation of plasmin. Its efficacy is equivalent to that of streptokinase, but alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen. All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted to some extent by administration of antifibrinolysins, such as aminocaproic acid.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, page no. 674
